message_content: Mom, I'll be right there to help you in the kitchen. Do you need me to bring some scallions, ginger, and garlic along?

Mom, I'm almost home. I'll be there in about ten minutes.

Alright, understood. I will proceed in the second direction, focusing on deepening the theme of "The Lively Atmosphere and Renewal of the Old Street." I will send you the detailed outline tomorrow morning.
Mom, I'm awake. I'll be out for breakfast in a bit.
Weiwei, is the desk tidied up? I've poured you a glass of warm water. Don't sit for too long; get up and move around a bit.
Dad, Mom, I've just finished work and will be there for dinner right away.
Alright, the dishes are all on the table, we're just waiting for you.

message_content: Me: Dad, I've finished reviewing and am about to head home from the library. I should be home around six.
Me: Mom, I'm almost home. I'd love to have your braised pork ribs for dinner tonight!
Mom, I'm a bit absorbed in my review. Please remember to call me for lunch at 12 noon sharp. I'm afraid I might forget again.
Jiajia, I started reviewing ancient Chinese literary theory this afternoon. Concepts like 'artistic conception' and 'poetic vigor' feel so abstract. How do you understand them?
Me: I made some comparative flashcards and feel much better now! I brewed a cup of milk tea as a reward during my break. Remember to balance work and rest, everyone.
Liu Jia: I've just finished integrating Chinese and Western literary theories and identified several challenging points. Would you like to discuss them together this evening?
Jingjing, did you sleep well last night? The weather is nice today. Wishing you a pleasant day!
Mom, I'm heading to the library and won't be back for lunch. I've brought an apple and some bread.
Wenwen, I'll probably arrive at the library around nine-thirty. Shall we meet at the usual spot?

Me: Jingjing, I don't have class tomorrow afternoon. Would you like to go to that newly opened café on Culture Lane and hang out? I heard the ambiance is quite nice.
Mom, I've finished reviewing. I'm going downstairs to eat. What delicious food are we having for lunch today?

Dad, Mom says we're having steamed pot chicken for lunch! I'm on my way to the dining room now.

Mom, I've finished my exams and I'm having a meal on Wenlin Street right now. I just discovered a new dish at a restaurant—mushroom chicken soup rice noodles—and it's especially delicious. The soup is incredibly flavorful! What did you and Dad have for lunch?

Sisi, I really enjoyed our walk in Cuihu Park this afternoon. The scenery with the red-billed gulls and withered lotus was truly beautiful. Thank you for spending the first day of my winter vacation with me!

Uncle Qin, I will arrive at the bookstore around 4:30. Today, I would like to look for some books on family history and local chronicles. Would it be convenient for you to help me keep an eye out for them?

Dear Editor Xu, 

I hope this message finds you well. The winter break plan has been preliminarily drafted, with a focus on completing the framework for the essay collection and 2-3 in-depth articles. Regarding the draft for "Urban Monsoon," I expect to submit the initial version for your review by January 25. Please let me know if this timeline works for you.
Jingjing, I plan to focus on writing manuscripts during the winter break, and I'm feeling a bit stressed. How have you been lately? Are you free to grab a coffee and chat over the weekend?

Editor Xu, I conducted research on transformation cases of independent bookstores in the city this morning and have prepared a preliminary outline of questions. When would be a convenient time for me to send it to you for review?
Lulu, I have booked the relaxation group class for this afternoon and will arrive at the studio around 15:30. My shoulders and neck feel particularly tight today, so please give me extra guidance.

Wenzi, I just got home. I visited three bookstores today and gained a lot. Regarding the topic of independent bookstores, my preliminary framework focuses on the locality of "cultural spaces." I'd like to hear your thoughts. Are you available for a voice call?

Your suggestion is absolutely crucial! 'Character stories outweigh spatial descriptions'—that really opened my eyes. I'll adjust the framework tonight to focus on the stories of the bookstore owner and the regular customers. Let's sync up on the progress next week and keep pushing forward together!

Professor Wu, thank you very much for your guidance this morning, which has greatly clarified the creative direction for "Roots and Veins." I have noted down the books you recommended, "Field Research and Oral History Methods" and "The Craft of Prose," and will study them as soon as possible. Once again, thank you for your valuable time!

【Sanlian Taofen Bookstore】Dear member, on January 17, 2025, at 13:05, you purchased two books: "Field Research and Oral History Methods" and "The Craft of Prose," with a total amount of 98.60 yuan. Points have been accumulated. Thank you for your support!
Dad, when we talked about visiting Honghe over dinner, I checked the map. Do you remember exactly which commune and which brigade it was? I'd like to do some preparation in advance.

Me: Dad, when we were talking about going back to Honghe over dinner, I checked the map. Do you still remember exactly which commune and which production brigade it was? I'd like to do some preparation in advance.
Mom, I'll be discussing the manuscript with the editor tonight, so I might stay up a bit late. You and Dad should rest early; there's no need to wait for me.

Editor Xu, the draft of the column article "Urban Cultural Living Room" has been sent to your email. Its core theme explores the value of physical bookstores as spiritual sanctuaries in the digital age. Please check and review it at your convenience.

The manuscript has been received. The tone of humanistic care is well established. It is suggested to add one or two specific case details about bookstores in the second part, such as the story of the shop owner or interactions with readers, to enhance the resonance of the "spiritual sanctuary." The revised draft can be submitted to me in three days.

Jingjing, I talked with my parents about my creative plan today. They were very supportive and even dug out some old photos. It feels like I'm one step closer to my dream, and my heart is filled with a sense of security.

Jingjing, I talked with my parents about my creative plans today. They were very supportive and even dug out some old photos. I feel like I'm one step closer to my dream, and it gives me a great sense of reassurance.
Mom, the fish and soup for dinner were both delicious. Thank you. I'm feeling much better now and will go to bed early tonight.
Mom, the honey water is very sweet. Thank you for keeping me company. I'm fine. I'll go to bed after finishing this episode of the documentary. You should rest early too.
Mom, I'm up now and feeling much better. I'll help you water the flowers later.

【Writing Workshop】Good morning, everyone. Today's lecture, "Emotional Restraint and Detail Tension in Nonfiction Writing," will begin promptly at 9:00. Please join the online meeting room in advance. The link has been updated in the group announcement.
Wenzi, are you attending the lecture this morning? The idea of "using a calm pen to write about surging emotions" really resonated with me. I’d love to discuss it with you.
Dad, during lunch today I'd like to ask about your thoughts when you were writing your educated youth diaries back then. It would be particularly helpful for my graduation project.

Dad, during this afternoon's online discussion, I shared excerpts from your diary about carrying water and hearing wolf howls. Everyone resonated deeply, saying your records are filled with resilience and poetry. You must be delighted to hear this!

Jingjing, I attended an online writing discussion this afternoon and shared my dad's diary. The response was fantastic! It felt really inspiring for creative work. I'll share more details with you later.

Wenzi, this afternoon's discussion was very fruitful. The conversation about personal narrative and public resonance has given me a clearer idea for the conception of "Roots and Veins." How is your writing going lately?
Lulu, I'm almost there. The traffic is a bit heavy today. Have you arrived yet?
Lulu, there are seats available at the Man Shiguang Cafe ahead. I'll go and save a seat first. You can come directly after class.

I: Manman, I've just completed a set of Ikenobo 'Shoka' arrangements with the theme 'Winter Resilience and Tranquil Beauty,' using wintersweet, silver willow, and holly berries. I've already posted the photos in our group chat. Please take a look when you have time—I'm looking forward to your feedback!

Mom, you've worked hard cleaning this morning! I've finished wiping the windows and bookshelf over here. Do you need my help with the floor and kitchen over there?
Mom, I'm going to the convenience store at the north gate to buy some fruit. Would you like oranges or strawberries? Or is there anything else you'd like?

Dad, I was tidying up the study just now and found an old wooden box containing several diaries you wrote in western Yunnan in 1975. I flipped through them—they are really well-written, and those little poems are particularly moving. May I continue reading them? This is truly the biggest surprise of the day.

Wenzi, I was doing a major cleaning at home today and unexpectedly discovered my father's long-dusty diary. The content is so shocking and has given me a lot of creative inspiration! It feels like the framework of "Roots and Veins" has suddenly become much clearer.

Mom, I've done a preliminary calculation of the budget for the essay collection, which is approximately 2,100 yuan, covering expenses such as material costs and investigation reserves. I'll discuss the details with you tonight.
Wenzi, today's conversation was truly enlightening. Thank you for your guidance! I will carefully reflect on the point about "letting objects speak." Rest early and good night.
Sis, I felt much more at ease after talking with you last night. Thank you for always being by my side—you are forever my strongest support. Happy New Year, love you!
Uncle, Happy New Year! I wish you and aunt good health and all the best in the new year! We've just prepared the tea and snacks, and we're waiting for you to arrive.
Aunt, Happy New Year! Wishing you endless smiles and the fulfillment of all your wishes! The house is all tidied up, and we're eagerly looking forward to your arrival.
Mom, when are Uncle and Aunt expected to arrive? I've already prepared the fruit platter and tea.

Brother Yuan, I really enjoyed our video call for the New Year greetings! I've noted down the game you recommended and will give it a try later. By the way, regarding the Yunnan ham you mentioned wanting to try last time, I've asked my parents to send you some.

He Lu, I've completed the summary of my yoga practice for January. I feel a noticeable improvement in core strength and greater emotional stability. message_content: Jingjing, I just got home, washed some blueberries and made tea. It feels so comfortable! The group chat says it's going to rain this weekend, so should we reschedule our original picnic plan?

While writing in my journal at the café this afternoon, I was reminded of what you said last time about "gifts carrying emotions," and it really resonated with me. How was your weekend?
Dad, I'm heading out for my flower arrangement class. I should be back around three or four in the afternoon. Please don't wait for me for lunch.
Manman, I'm almost at the studio. Have you arrived yet? The Nandina branches I brought today are absolutely stunning!
I just arrived at the door as well! Waiting for you—hurry and let me see your Nandina!

Jingjing, the tea set you gave my dad for his birthday has arrived. It's white porcelain and looks absolutely beautiful! I was extra careful when washing it. Are you free this weekend? Come over to my place for some tea.

message_content: Dad, I'm going to the old street this afternoon to watch the film "Memories of Spring City," the documentary related to oral history that you mentioned this morning. I'll share my thoughts with you after watching it!
Dad, I'm heading out to Cuihu Lake to buy some stationery supplies for my journal and will be back for lunch. Please be careful on your way to meet your old colleagues this afternoon.
Jingjing, I just bought a set of super cute Yunnan plant stickers at Cuihu Lake! I plan to use them in my new journal. How has your journaling been going lately?

Editor Xu, while working on the chapter about urban transformation in the manuscript this afternoon, I incorporated some new ideas, which I believe have enriched the content. The first draft is expected to be ready for your review next week.
Dad, I'm almost home. What's for breakfast?
Mom, I'm heading out to the café. Please remember to bring in the clothes on the balcony. The weather forecast says it might rain this afternoon.

Editor Xu, I spent the afternoon organizing materials at the café and took the opportunity to review the final draft of the manuscript once more. I believe it is ready for finalization. The electronic version will be sent to your email shortly, and the hard copy will be mailed to you tomorrow.

Wenzi, I'm currently organizing materials for the annual review. How exactly do you implement the dual-axis classification method based on 'emotional warmth' and 'temporal density' that you mentioned earlier? My materials here are a bit disorganized.

Song Wen: I've drawn a simple quadrant chart and sent it to your WeChat. The horizontal axis represents time density, and the vertical axis represents emotional temperature. Place the events into the chart, and the central point of the quadrant will reveal your annual core theme. Give it a try first.

Editor Xu, the final manuscript has been sent to your work email. Please check it. The attachment includes the PDF of the manuscript and the preliminary draft of the cover design. Is the mailing address still the old address of the publishing house?

Xu Mingyuan: The email has been received. The quality of the final draft is excellent. The address remains unchanged: Publisher, XX Road, Chaoyang District, Beijing, recipient Xu Mingyuan. Please inform me of the tracking number once it has been shipped.

Wenzi, I tried your method. The Dali field trip and my father's birthday indeed both fall within the high-emotion zone, which helped me clarify the main storyline! Thank you so much. Next time you come to Kunming, I'll treat you to coffee.
Mom, I'm up and will be right over for breakfast.

Professor Wu, the first draft of my essay collection "Whispers of Cang'er, Mountains of My Father's Generation" has been completed. I have sent the email to your work address and would be grateful if you could review it and provide your feedback at your convenience. Thank you for your guidance all along!
Jingjing, I've finally sent out my manuscript! I plan to relax by working on my scrapbook this afternoon. How have you been lately?

Dad, I'll be organizing the study and reviewing finances at home this morning, going to the bookstore for inspiration in the afternoon, and have a yoga class in the evening. What would you and Mom like for lunch? I'll help Mom prepare it together.
Mom, let me help you wash the vegetables and peel the garlic. I just finished tidying up the study this morning, and I feel particularly refreshed.
【Zhijia Convenience Store】Dear member, the points in your account will expire and be cleared at 24:00 today. Please use them promptly. Click the link to redeem products or coupons.
Manman, I saw a book about the history of the Ikenobo school at the bookstore, and the illustrations are absolutely stunning! I'm sending you the link—check it out if you're interested.

I: The link is for the 'SDX Joint Publishing Company Online Store'. By the way, regarding the flower market you mentioned last time, what specific date after the Chinese New Year should we go? My planner has arrived, so I can start planning accordingly.

Su Man: I've read the book, and it's really good! The flower market will open on the eighth day after the Chinese New Year. How about we go on the morning of the tenth? There probably won't be too many people then.
Sun Yuwei: Hello Auntie Xie, this is Yuwei. Thank you for sharing your health tips with me yesterday morning at Cuihu Park. I've taken notes. Let's take a walk together another day.

Li Xiulan: Are you done hanging the laundry? There are two more shirts in the kitchen.
Sun Yuwei: Mom, I'm coming out.

Sun Mingyuan: Weiwei, don't worry if your computer breaks down. I checked, and the largest official Lenovo repair center in Kunming is on North Huancheng Road, I think it's called the Central Store. You should look up the exact location and go there directly, and remember to bring your warranty card.

Sun Yuwei: I just finished calculating taxes at the library, and the amount I need to pay back is too high. The pressure is immense, and suddenly I feel a tightness in my chest, making it hard to breathe.
In the afternoon, I took an inspiring stroll through Cuihu Park and jotted down the keyword 'Narrative of Light and Shadow' in my phone's memo app, which proved quite helpful for writing material.
Sun Yuwei: Just finished a meeting with my supervisor. He recommended two books, "The Art of Nonfiction" and "Writing My Life Poetry," saying they could inspire my prose writing.

Su Man: We chose eucalyptus leaves for today's floral arrangement, which I think pairs well with the early spring theme.  
Sun Yuwei: Yes, the lines of the snow willow are also quite elegant.
Shall we go to the "Narratives on Paper" exhibition recommended by Boss Qin Mingyuan at the bookstore yesterday? Let's plan for Saturday afternoon.
Yuwei, regarding that article on the bookstore theme, I have already sent my suggestions. Please check your email.

Vivi, the video idea you mentioned during breakfast is excellent, and Mom supports you. However, please don't stay up late like last night—make sure to get enough rest. Inspiration is important, but your health is even more crucial.
Dad, the procedures are done, and the computer is fixed. However, the engineer confirmed the issue—it requires a motherboard replacement, and the cost is quite high. Are we almost home?
The submission email has been sent. Now I'm heading to the bookstore to read the recommended collection of essays and relax.
Chen Sisi: Yuwei, regarding the 'Urban Memory' photography exhibition you inquired about, I have compiled the exhibition details and curator information for you and will send them to you shortly.

Zhang Jing: Yuwei, how have you been lately? I was scrolling through my Moments yesterday and saw that Li Haoran posted what seemed like a rather emotional status, saying something like "a grain of sand in the times" or something along those lines.
Sun Yuwei: Sigh, I was just about to tell you. He reached out to me for a chat the other day and seemed quite down.
Zhang Jing: Huh? What happened? Wasn't he doing quite well at that big company in Shenzhen before?

Sun Yuwei: Yes, but he said his company recently underwent a business restructuring, and the entire project team he was responsible for was eliminated, so everyone in the group had to leave. He is now temporarily unemployed.
Zhang Jing: Oh my goodness, so sudden... What does he plan to do next then?

Sun Yuwei: He said he would take a break and adjust first, then start sending out resumes. Shenzhen has many opportunities, but the competition is also intense. I comforted him a few words, feeling that he was under a lot of pressure.
Song Wen: Wenzi, have you read any good books lately? I feel like I'm running out of things to read.
Sun Yuwei: I've recently become fascinated with a certain type of book that really suits my taste.
Song Wen: Quick, tell me, which category?

Sun Yuwei: It's like the author uses a magnifying glass to observe their own city, documenting the daily lives of ordinary people in the streets, small shops, markets, and parks, then compiling these observations into a collection of essays. It’s not grand narratives, but rather subtle, specific, and warm slices of life.

Song Wen: Wow, that sounds perfect for the tone of your "Footsteps in Spring City" column! This kind of nonfiction writing, rooted in specific spaces and daily life, can truly provide a lot of inspiration. Do you have a specific reading list? Send it to me!
Song Wen: Yuwei, are you there? I'm feeling a bit down and would like to talk with you.
Sun Yuwei: Wenzi, I'm here. What's wrong? What happened?

Song Wen: Do you remember the online photography exhibition I mentioned to you last month? It's called 'Urban Folds'. I put a lot of effort into capturing a series of photos of the old teahouses on Yulin Road, aiming to document that sense of community that is on the verge of disappearing.

Sun Yuwei: I remember you mentioned that the theme of the exhibition is excellent and aligns well with the urban observation project you've always wanted to pursue. How is the filming of the documentary progressing?

The results came out today, and I wasn't selected. The judges' feedback was that the "perspective is too sentimental and lacks critical analysis." Sigh, I feel like my aesthetic sense and expression aren't being recognized, and I'm starting to doubt myself a bit.
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, have you been listening to any new songs lately? My playlist is almost exhausted, I need some recommendations!
Sun Yuwei: Haha, there really is! I recently discovered a treasure of a band called 'Huan Chao' from Ningbo.
Zhang Jing: Huanchao? That's a very unique name. What style is it?

Sun Yuwei: They sing in the Ningbo dialect, with a style that is somewhat folk, yet also carries elements of retro pop and psychedelia. I couldn’t understand the lyrics at all, but the damp, nostalgic, slightly melancholic yet warm atmosphere instantly captivated me.
Zhang Jing: That sounds so interesting! To feel the atmosphere of the music beyond the lyrics themselves—that's so 'Sun Yuwei'! Send me the album name quickly; I want to listen to it too.

Weiwei, this morning's walk left me with many reflections. Sharing stories from my youth when I was sent to the countryside with you has lightened my heart considerably. You asked me about my outlook on the days ahead—to be honest, I feel both hopeful and a bit hollow. But seeing how thoughtful and determined you are now brings me great comfort. Rest early.
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, how have you been lately? How is the progress on the prose collection?
Sun Yuwei: I'm still organizing my father's diaries, and the progress is a bit slow. How about you? Are your students easy to manage lately?
Zhang Jing: Not bad, just a bit tired. By the way, Xinran video called me yesterday and spent quite a while complaining.
Sun Yuwei: What happened to her? Is she under too much work pressure?

Zhang Jing: It's not about work, it's a minor emotional issue. She said a new male colleague at the company seems to be interested in her, always finding various excuses to invite her to meals and giving her small gifts. Xinran feels a bit annoyed, but since they are colleagues, she doesn't want to be too blunt in her refusal, fearing it might create awkwardness at work later on.
Song Wen: Yuwei, is that ASMR sleep aid you mentioned last time really effective? I've been having trouble sleeping lately.
Sun Yuwei: It's quite useful for me! I listen to it for a while before bed now, which helps me relax. You can give it a try—there are plenty of resources online.
Do you have any recommendations? I've searched, and there are so many varieties that I'm not sure which one is suitable.

Sun Yuwei: It depends on personal preference. I love the rustling sound of turning pages and writing with a fountain pen on paper the most. It gives me a special sense of security, as if I’ve returned to my student days studying in the library. I’ve also tried the sound of rain and combing my hair, but neither relaxes me as much as this does.
Song Wen: Haha, as expected of a Chinese literature major! I'll give it a try tomorrow. Thanks!

Shen Wei: Yuwei, what are you up to? I've been under a lot of work pressure lately. A female colleague in our team, whom I get along with quite well, has had some family issues, and she's been feeling really down.
Sun Yuwei: Huh? What happened? Is it serious?

Shen Wei: It was quite sudden. Her father is in their hometown, and he suffered a sudden cerebral infarction two days ago. He was rushed to the hospital for emergency treatment and is still under observation in the hospital. She has been shuttling between Hangzhou and her hometown these past two days, and she looks quite haggard.
Sun Yuwei: Oh my, I hope the elderly can recover soon. This is truly a trying time.
Song Wen: Yuwei, what books have you been reading lately? Any good recommendations? I've been running out of things to read recently.
Sun Yuwei: My reading preferences have changed quite a bit recently. I used to particularly enjoy those heavy, dramatic historical novels, feeling they had a grand scope.

Sun Yuwei: But now, I find myself even more drawn to essays and prose that depict the trivialities of daily life—the small details, the plants and trees. For example, works by writers like Wang Zengqi and Zhou Zuoren, or contemporary authors writing about urban corners, wet markets, and the transformations of old streets.
Song Wen: Wow, this shift is interesting! Is it related to your current work on the essay collection and organizing your father's diaries? It feels like you're moving from "faraway" to "nearby."

Sun Yuwei: Now that you mention it, that's true! Perhaps subconsciously, I've been seeking a texture and warmth that feels closer to life itself. After seeing so many grand narratives, I find the details of everyday life even more moving.
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, how have you been lately? The atmosphere in our office is a bit heavy today.
Sun Yuwei: What's wrong, Jingjing? What happened?

Zhang Jing: Ms. Li from our office, the one who teaches fifth-grade Chinese, her father had a sudden cerebral hemorrhage yesterday and is still in the ICU. She took leave today, and several of us colleagues are discussing visiting her over the weekend.
Sun Yuwei: Oh my goodness, this is so sudden. I hope the elderly person can pull through. When you go, please also convey my regards to Teacher Li on my behalf.
Uncle Qin: Yuwei, I've noticed you've been wearing headphones while writing at the bookstore recently, and your efficiency seems quite high. What good music are you listening to?

Sun Yuwei: Hello, Uncle Qin! I recently discovered a treasure trove of a playlist, all featuring Lo-Fi music with ambient sounds. For example, it simulates the sound of rain or the background chatter in a café. It really helps me focus without being too monotonous.

Uncle Qin: That's a brilliant choice. It creates a specific visual imagery without interfering with one's thoughts like music with vocals would. It's somewhat like providing a comfortable background board for the brain.
Sun Yuwei: Yes, that's exactly the feeling! It has a bit more life to it than a simple piano piece, yet it allows me to sink deeper than jazz does.
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, have you heard? Li Haoran seems to have been promoted recently!
Sun Yuwei: Really? I haven't been in touch with him much lately. What exactly is the situation?
Zhang Jing: I also heard it from Wang Xinran. Haoran is doing quite well at that internet company in Shenzhen. It seems he was just promoted to be the head of a new product line.

Sun Yuwei: Wow, congratulations to him! He was already very thoughtful in high school, and now he's doing so well. However, he's in Shenzhen, which is too far away from us. His promotion doesn't really affect our lives here, but we're just happy for him.
Zhang Jing: Indeed, I'm happy for him. Next time he returns to Kunming, he'll have to treat us!
Shen Wei: Yuwei, have you been listening to any new songs lately? Could you recommend some that are suitable for listening to while writing?

Sun Yuwei: Sis, my taste in music has changed quite a bit lately. I used to enjoy pop songs with lyrics, but now I actually prefer post-rock or instrumental music that relies more on atmosphere and instrumentation, with little to no lyrics.
Shen Wei: Oh? Why the sudden interest in this? Does it feel related to your recent state while writing the essay collection?

Sun Yuwei: Possibly. This type of music lacks specific lyrical direction, which actually gives me more room for imagination. Listening to it while brainstorming articles or working on my journal allows my thoughts to drift further, without being confined by fixed emotions.
Shen Wei: Understood, that aligns well with your current state. Could you recommend a few bands or playlists for me to try?
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, what are you up to? I just finished a video call with Xinran, and she seemed a bit down.
Sun Yuwei: I've just finished writing the draft. What's wrong with Xinran? Is she under a lot of work pressure?

Zhang Jing: Yes, she was recently assigned to lead a brand-new project on "Copyright Definition for AI-Generated Content." She mentioned that this field is so new that many boundaries are still quite ambiguous.
Sun Yuwei: That does sound quite challenging, as it involves many overlapping areas of technology and law.

Zhang Jing: Yes, Xinran said what troubles her most is not the technical implementation, but the underlying ethical issues. For instance, after AI "learns" from human works, who owns the copyright of its output? She feels the responsibility of making such judgments is too heavy, almost suffocating.
Shen Wei: Yuwei, I heard you're thinking about changing your computer recently? Have you found any models that catch your eye?
Sun Yuwei: Yes, Sister Weiwei, my old laptop is almost on its last legs. I've looked at a few models and am feeling a bit overwhelmed by the choices.
Shen Wei: Since you mainly use it for writing and looking up information, you don't need to pursue top-tier performance, right? I think portability might be more important for you.

Sun Yuwei: Portability is certainly a consideration, but what I care about most is actually the screen. I spend seven to eight hours a day looking at literature, writing drafts, and editing photos on the screen, which really strains my eyes.

Sun Yuwei: So my primary screening criterion now is screen quality, particularly color accuracy, and whether it includes good eye protection technologies like low blue light and flicker-free features. Performance is actually not the top priority; it just needs to be sufficient.
Yuwei, are you busy? I want to vent about my cousin. She's almost depressed from work lately.
Sun Yuwei: Just finished writing the draft, what's up? Didn't your cousin just find a copywriting job at an advertising company in Chengdu?

Song Wen: Yes, that's the job. She took on a project for an automotive brand, and the client was particularly difficult to deal with. They revised the copy over a dozen times, and the direction kept changing.
Sun Yuwei: Oh my god, this is so torturous. Repeated revisions really drain the creative passion.

Song Wen: Yeah, she's been complaining to me every day lately, saying she feels like everything she writes is garbage and starting to doubt whether she's even cut out for this line of work. I really don't know how to comfort her. Since you're also a writer, you might understand that feeling better.
Zhou Lin: Yuwei, have you come across any good books lately? I'm in a reading slump and looking for some inspiration.
Sun Yuwei: I haven't been reading many novels lately; instead, I've become fascinated by a particular type of essay.
Zhou Lin: Oh? What kind of prose? It's not the overly academic type, is it?

Sun Yuwei: It's not academic. It's a type of non-fiction work where the author recalls and reflects on memories and thoughts centered around a specific everyday object, such as an old chair, an enamel cup, or a book read in childhood.

Sun Yuwei: I find it particularly touching. It connects personal history with a sense of the era through objects, and the language is very unadorned. I’ve recently been looking for several collections of this kind in bookstores to read.

Sun Yuwei, how is the progress on the core chapters of your thesis? Regarding the theoretical framework of 'urban writing' we discussed last time, do you have any new thoughts on its application in case studies?

Yuwei, I just sent you the link to the electronic version of the book "Family Album: Photography and Memory" we discussed today via WeChat. I think the section on "How to Tell Family Stories Through the Lens" particularly resonates with the theme of our discussion tonight.

I: Xiaoyun, the brisk walk at Green Lake this morning was totally worth it! Not only were the water lilies in bloom, but I also came across a very stylish elderly gentleman playing the hulusi by the lake. The melody was absolutely beautiful, and it feels like I’ll be in a great mood all day! Would you like to come for a walk this weekend too?
Professor Wang: Meet at the campus coffee shop at 3 p.m., and bring your initial ideas.
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, what are you up to? I just finished grading the assignments, and I'm exhausted.
Sun Yuwei: Just finished writing a piece of prose and am taking a break. You've been working hard too—being a teacher is truly not easy.
Zhang Jing: Yes. By the way, have you been in touch with Li Haoran recently? He popped up in our high school class group chat yesterday and seemed a bit down.

Sun Yuwei: We had a brief chat last week. He mentioned that he has been under immense work pressure recently. It seems that after the launch of a new feature for a product he is responsible for, both user feedback and data have fallen far short of expectations. Now he has to start from scratch to re-evaluate the product logic and user needs, which has left him completely overwhelmed.
Zhang Jing: Sigh, that's just how the internet industry is—fast-paced and high-pressure. I hope he can adjust soon. We'll get together properly when we go back for the New Year and cheer him up.

Shen Wei: Yuwei, a new milk tea shop has recently opened in Hangzhou, and their brown sugar pearl milk tea is particularly popular, with incredibly long lines. You're the expert in this area, so please enlighten me—what exactly should be the standard for a good brown sugar pearl milk tea?
Sun Yuwei: Haha, I wouldn't call myself an expert—I've just had enough experience to form some opinions. When I choose brown sugar bubble tea, I focus on two key aspects.

Sun Yuwei: The first is the flavor of the brown sugar. It cannot be that cloyingly sweet artificial saccharin taste; it must be a rich, natural flavor that comes from slow cooking, with a hint of caramelization and mineral notes, and it should coat the cup beautifully.

Sun Yuwei: The second aspect is the pearls themselves. They shouldn't be too hard, nor should they dissolve immediately upon a gentle press. They should have a soft, glutinous texture with just the right amount of chewiness, providing a noticeable presence in the mouth that contrasts with the smoothness of the brown sugar milk tea. As for sweetness, I think it can be adjusted and isn't the primary criterion.
Shen Wei: Got it! No wonder you're a seasoned enthusiast – your description is making my mouth water. I'll try that new restaurant based on your standards and let you know about my experience later!
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, what are you up to? I just finished a video call with Xinran, and she has some big news on her end.
Sun Yuwei: I'm working on a draft. What's the big news? Has Xinran been promoted again?

Zhang Jing: It's not a promotion, but a transfer! A new project team has been established within their company, dedicated to developing an online product related to urban cultural memory, something like a combination of digital archives and community stories. Because Xinran had previously worked on some local lifestyle products, she was noticed by the leadership and transferred to this team.
Sun Yuwei: Wow! This sounds amazing, it's exactly the kind of direction she would be interested in. She must be thrilled, right?

Zhang Jing: Exactly, she was incredibly excited in the video, saying that although the pressure might be high, she could finally do something she truly finds meaningful. She also mentioned that when working on the Kunming section in the future, she might need to seek your advice.
Lin Yue: Yuwei, have you been listening to any new songs lately? My playlist is almost exhausted, I need some recommendations!
Sun Yuwei: Yueyue! My taste in music has changed a lot recently. I used to prefer pop songs with lyrics, but now I’m actually into music with very little or no vocals.
Lin Yue: What? You've switched to pure music? What kind specifically?

Sun Yuwei: Well, mainly ambient music, and also minimalist classical music like that of Max Richter and Ólafur Arnalds. I play it when I'm writing or doing my journaling. It really helps me calm down, and my train of thought doesn't get interrupted.
Lin Yue: That sounds perfect for your current state! Send me the playlist link, I'll also try to see if I can find a moment of tranquility in the noisy office, haha.
Zhang Wei: Yuwei, are you free this afternoon? I'd like to discuss the content of the contract practice lecture you attended today. It seems quite helpful for freelancing.

Shen Wei: Yuwei, are you busy? I just got off the phone with my mom, and we were talking about the family's real estate matters. It suddenly reminded me of a recent issue one of our office colleagues encountered.
Sun Yuwei: Just finished writing a piece. What trouble? Related to real estate?

Shen Wei: Exactly. My colleague is from Yunnan, and his parents have an old house in Kunming. He recently wanted to settle down and buy a house in Hangzhou, but he was a bit short on the down payment. So, he thought of asking his parents to sell the old house to support him. However, it turned out that only his father's name was on the property deed for that house, and his mother passed away a few years ago.
Sun Yuwei: Ah, does that involve inheritance?

Shen Wei: Exactly! Now his father can't directly sell the house alone. They need to first clarify the portion of the property rights that belonged to his mother through inheritance notarization. Either he and his father inherit it together, or he gives up his inheritance rights, leaving it entirely to his father. The procedures are particularly complicated and require the presence or notarized authorization of all legal heirs. He also has grandparents (although they are very elderly). Everything got stuck all of a sudden, and they couldn't even gather the down payment. He was extremely anxious.

Song Wen: Yuwei, I read your recent essay about the morning mist at Cuihu Lake. It's truly wonderful! Especially the way you handled the sounds—it seems a bit different from your usual style, doesn't it?
Sun Yuwei: You've caught me. I've indeed been experimenting with some new descriptive approaches recently.
Song Wen: Tell me quickly! Did you read another book that inspired you?

Sun Yuwei: Not exactly books. It was one day when I was writing at home with the windows closed, but I could hear the faint, muffled sound of traffic outside, as if blocked by several buildings, along with intermittent birdcalls faintly drifting from some balcony. In that moment, I felt that these "incomplete" sounds had more flavor than clear ones.

Sun Yuwei: That's why I particularly enjoy depicting sound fragments filtered through distance, walls, or mist. I don't specify exactly what it is—I only provide an outline, leaving the rest for readers to imagine and fill in. I feel this approach makes the scene more detached, yet also quieter and more powerful.
I just had a conversation with Uncle Qin at Mingyuan Bookstore. He shared some insightful views on how local culture is represented in contemporary literary writing, which was quite enlightening.
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, how have you been lately? I saw on your WeChat Moments that you went to a bookstore for inspiration?
Sun Yuwei: Well, I'm looking for materials for my column. By the way, I had a video call with Xinran yesterday, and she didn't seem to be in a good state.
Zhang Jing: What's wrong? Is the work pressure too much?

Sun Yuwei: Not entirely due to pressure. She mentioned that her current job has become increasingly repetitive, lacking a sense of challenge and growth, as if she has hit a plateau. She feels somewhat lost and is considering whether to change jobs or even switch careers to explore other directions, but she is also worried about the risks.
Zhang Jing: Sigh, there are also troubles behind the halo of big companies. Let's find some time to console her together in the group chat.
Zhou Lin: Darling, what are you up to? How's your writing going lately? Any new songs to recommend?
Sun Yuwei: I'm currently working on the next chapter of "Footsteps in Spring City," which is about the morning and evening scenes of Green Lake. As for music, I've recently changed my taste.
Zhou Lin: Oh? No longer listening to your independent folk and light music?

Sun Yuwei: Hmm, I've found that pure music with some natural sounds suits my current state better. For example, ambient music with background sounds like rain, flowing streams, or crackling campfires helps me calm down more quickly, get into the writing flow, and doesn't disrupt my train of thought. It's also very relaxing to listen to while journaling or meditating in the evening.
Zhou Lin: That sounds very soothing! Please share the playlist! I also need some background music to counter Shenzhen's fast-paced lifestyle.
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, what are you up to? I just finished a video call with Xinran, and she seems to be under a lot of pressure lately.
Sun Yuwei: I'm organizing my journal. What happened to Xinran? Hasn't she always been very capable?
Zhang Jing: That's right, but this time she's in charge of a brand-new project, which seems to be about "AI and Content Creation." The concept is quite cutting-edge.

Zhang Jing: The problem lies in coordination. She said the technology, product, and marketing departments have completely different ideas, making communication particularly difficult. The project progress is now stuck, and she feels caught in the middle and very uncomfortable.
Sun Yuwei: That does sound tricky. Let's find a time to cheer her up together in the group chat.
Song Wen: Wenzi, what books have you been reading lately? I need some recommendations, as I'm running a bit low on reading material.

Sun Yuwei: My reading preferences have shifted a bit recently. I used to prefer pure prose and fiction, but now I'm particularly fascinated by books that observe a city as if it were a living organism.

Sun Yuwei: It's a type of non-fiction documentary literature where the author, like a detective, uncovers the collective memory of a place and the individual stories of the people living there through buildings, streets, and old photographs.
Song Wen: Wow, that sounds profound and fascinating! Is it related to your city stroll column? Such books should be quite helpful for exploring local cultural materials.

Sun Yuwei: Yes, it's closely related. Reading such books has given me a new perspective on familiar streets, and I feel like there are more materials I can write about. I recommend you read "Invisible Cities" and "River Town." Although they are not exactly the same genre, the subtlety of observation in them is quite similar.
Lin Yue: Yuwei, are you free for a video call tonight? I'd like to chat with you.
Sun Yuwei: Sure, I'm free after nine. What's up? You sound a bit worried from your tone?
Lin Yue: Well, it's about Chen Mo. Do you remember Chen Mo from our class, the one with excellent writing skills?
Sun Yuwei: As I recall, she went to work as an editor at a publishing house after graduation, didn't she?

Lin Yue: Yes. I spoke with her on the phone yesterday, and she was in a really bad state. She broke up with her boyfriend of over three years, and it hit her particularly hard. I heard she’s been absent-minded at work lately and even got called out by her supervisor. Sigh, it’s really worrying.
Shen Wei: Yuwei, what have you been up to lately? The playlist you shared on your Moments seems different from before.
Sun Yuwei: Hello Sister Wei! Recently, I've been mainly focused on writing a collection of essays and preparing the textual content for a photography exhibition.
Shen Wei: No wonder. Didn't you used to love listening to pop songs with lyrics? Now there are so many instrumental tracks in your playlist.

Sun Yuwei: Hmm, it feels different now. When I'm writing, especially when deep thinking is required, I can't listen to songs with vocals at all—they distract me. Instead, some post-rock with a strong atmospheric vibe, or ethereal instrumental music, helps me get into the zone faster. It feels like everything around me quiets down.
Shen Wei: I see, that aligns well with your current creative state. It seems you've found your own "flow" BGM.
Zhang Jing: Weiwei, what are you up to? I just heard some news and feel a bit emotional.
Sun Yuwei: I'm revising the manuscript. What's the message?
Zhang Jing: Regarding Li Haoran. You remember him, right? The one from the high school literature club who later became a product manager in Shenzhen.
Sun Yuwei: Of course I remember, we still chat occasionally. What happened to him?

Zhang Jing: His company recently had a major layoff, and he was on the list. Yesterday, I saw him post a rather cryptic reflection on his social media feed. I confirmed it with him privately. Sigh, the internet industry in Shenzhen seems particularly turbulent this year.
Zhou Lin: Yuwei, have you been listening to any new songs lately? My playlist is almost exhausted, and I need to replenish some spiritual nourishment.

Sun Yuwei: Haha, my taste has changed recently. I used to listen to pop and folk music, but lately while writing papers and organizing photos, I found I needed some background music that allows immersion without being too distracting.
Zhou Lin: So? Did you find the treasure?

Sun Yuwei: Exactly! I've become fascinated with ambient electronic music. Especially the kind that incorporates natural field recordings, like the sound of rain or wind, blended with soothing synth melodies. The top ten tracks in my loop playlist are basically all in this style. It feels like it can calm the mind, and it's particularly suitable when I need to focus.
Zhou Lin: Wow, that sounds really sophisticated! Please share a few playlists or artists with me so I can give them a try. I'm already tired of listening to post-rock and City Pop.
To Wang Ting: The anxiety has subsided significantly, thanks to that sweet drink.
Miss Sun, I noticed you were writing and didn't want to disturb you. The hot water kettle at the counter has been refilled. Please help yourself if needed.
Wu Mingyuan: Yuwei, today's discussion was very pleasant. Remember to check out the two theoretical reference books I recommended; they will be helpful for your essay collection outline.

Song Wen recommended Nutstore as the cloud backup tool. For computers, he mentioned the Lenovo Xiaoxin series, noting that buying them on JD.com is cost-effective. Regarding mindset, he emphasized that it is an essential lesson for freelancers.

Zhang Jing: Yuwei, have you been in touch with Xinran recently? I feel like she's been a bit down lately.
Sun Yuwei: Well, we had a video chat last night. She's facing some obstacles at work.
Zhang Jing: Huh? Is it still that product project she invested a lot of effort in? I remember she said it was about to launch.

Sun Yuwei: Yes, that's the one. She said that after the launch, both user growth and retention data fell short of internal expectations. The boss is putting a lot of pressure on them, demanding a review.

Sun Yuwei: Moreover, there is some internal chaos within the team. Some believe the product direction was flawed from the start, while others feel the operations didn’t keep up. There are significant internal disagreements, and she is caught in the middle, finding it very difficult to navigate.
Zhou Lin: Yuwei, have you read any good books lately? I'm running out of books to read.

Sun Yuwei: My reading preferences have changed quite a bit recently. I used to read a little bit of everything, but now I am particularly fascinated by nonfiction works about southwestern regions of China, such as Yunnan, Guizhou, and Sichuan.
Zhou Lin: Wow, shifting to a rural documentary style? Is it because you're preparing your collection of essays?

Sun Yuwei: Yes, it's very much related. Reading texts that delve into villages, document the lives of ordinary people, and depict landscapes and customs feels particularly substantial. It provides me with a lot of inspiration regarding "place" and "people."

Sun Yuwei: For example, I've recently been reading Liangshan Chronicles, as well as a book about southeast Guizhou called In Search of Villages. Neither of them are novels, but they are more powerful than novels.
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, have you heard? Li Haoran doesn't seem to be doing well lately.
Sun Yuwei: Huh? What's wrong? Is it something work-related?
Zhang Jing: It's not about work, it's about relationships. He broke up with his girlfriend of three years.
Sun Yuwei: How could this happen? Their relationship seemed quite stable before.
Zhang Jing: I heard he's been under immense pressure from his recent project, working overtime every day. The communication between them has dwindled, and conflicts eventually erupted. What a pity.
Song Wen: Yuwei, what books have you been reading lately? Do you have any good recommendations for someone like me who's in a reading slump?

Sun Yuwei: Haha, my reading preferences have shifted a bit lately. Since I've been working on the oral history project of old streets and alleys, I've become particularly fascinated with books on urban memory.
Song Wen: Urban Memory? What specific type of book is it?

Sun Yuwei: It refers to that kind of non-fiction work exploring how urban spaces carry personal and collective memories. For example, works in the vein of Invisible Cities, or some urban observation notes written by journalists and scholars. I feel they can provide a lot of inspiration for my writing regarding the "sense of place."
Song Wen: Understood, it sounds profound but also very interesting. Please send me a copy of the book list you think is good when you have a chance!
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, I've been feeling a bit down lately. Xiao Zhao from our office, that particularly cheerful girl, her father suddenly had a cerebral infarction and was hospitalized.
Sun Yuwei: What? So sudden! Is it serious? What's the current situation?

Zhang Jing: Still under observation in the ICU. The doctor said it was detected relatively early, but the subsequent recovery will be a long process. Xiao Zhao has been shuttling between school and the hospital these past few days and looks quite worn out. A few of us colleagues pooled some money as a gesture of support and have also helped share some of her workload.
Sun Yuwei: I hope your uncle recovers soon. Family members go through the most during times like these. Please comfort Xiao Zhao more, and also take care not to overexert yourself.
Yuwei, how is your writing going lately? I'm stuck with my manuscript and feel like I need some music to stimulate my inspiration.
Sun Yuwei: I'm doing okay. Recently I discovered a treasure of a playlist, full of light music with natural white noise, like the sound of rain, streams, and campfires.
Song Wen: Oh? That sounds very therapeutic. Is it effective?

Sun Yuwei: Extremely useful! It feels like it helps me quickly enter a calm, focused state, blocking out other noises, yet without the occasional interference to my train of thought that pure music sometimes causes. It's especially fitting when writing essays and urban observation pieces.
Got it! I'll go search for it right now. Thanks!
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, have you heard? It seems something has happened at Li Haoran's company.
Sun Yuwei: Huh? What happened? Wasn't he working as a product manager at that internet company in Shenzhen?

Zhang Jing: Yes, it's his project team. I heard the entire team was laid off. He didn't say much in the high school class group chat yesterday, but he mentioned to me privately that he's currently out of a job.
Sun Yuwei: Oh my god, so sudden. What is he planning to do now?

Zhang Jing: He said he first applied for unemployment benefits, which he can receive for a period of time to serve as a buffer. Meanwhile, he is both submitting resumes and looking for opportunities through referrals from friends. It seems his mindset is still okay, but the pressure is definitely high.
Song Wen: Yuwei, what books have you been reading lately? Could you recommend some to me? I'm running out of books to read.
Sun Yuwei: Lately, I feel like I've fallen into a fixed reading "comfort zone."
Song Wen: What comfort zone? Tell me about it.

Sun Yuwei: I'm particularly fascinated by that kind of nonfiction prose that writes about urban corners, wet markets, old streets, and an ordinary person's day. It feels like you can savor the true essence of life from these most mundane descriptions, which is also very inspiring for my own writing of "Spring City Chats." Works like "Tokyo Bookstores" and "The Flavor of Daily Life" are ones I've been revisiting frequently lately.
Song Wen: Got it, so it's "writing in place." That tone really suits your current state and creative direction. Send me the book list later!
Shen Wei: Yuwei, guess who I ran into at a newly opened bookstore by West Lake yesterday?
Sun Yuwei: Who is it? I don't know many of your friends in Hangzhou.
Shen Wei: Tang Lei! That quite active boy from your junior high school, the one nicknamed 'Stone'.
Sun Yuwei: Ah! Shi Tou! I remember him, he later went to Shenzhen to work in the internet industry. How did he end up going to Hangzhou?

Shen Wei: He said he came to Hangzhou for an interview. The pressure in Shenzhen is too high, and a startup company in Hangzhou has offered him a position in the field of AI content generation. He is quite tempted and is currently struggling with whether to make the move.

Song Wen: I've been working on an article about "the sense of ritual in reading" lately, and I'd like to ask you, aside from the content, do you pay special attention to the binding and design of books when purchasing them?

Sun Yuwei: Yes. Previously, I might have paid more attention to whether the cover looked appealing, but now I care more about the tactile experience of holding it in my hands and the convenience of reading.
Song Wen: Could you elaborate? For instance, what books have you purchased recently that felt particularly satisfying in terms of their "tactile quality"?

Sun Yuwei: Last week at Mingyuan Bookstore, Uncle Qin recommended a collection of essays by a Japanese author to me. It wasn't one of those elaborate, hefty volumes, but rather a 'pocket-sized' edition made with lightweight paper and featuring exposed spine thread-sewn binding. The cover design is extremely minimalist, displaying only the title and the author's name on an elegant, plain beige background.

Sun Yuwei: It feels exceptionally light in hand and can be laid completely flat, making it effortless to carry in a bag when going out. I’ve developed a particular fondness for books with this minimalist, portable, and reader-friendly "bunkobon" style. They feel closer to the essence of "reading" itself, rather than serving merely as decoration.
Shen Wei: Yuwei, guess who I ran into at a newly opened independent café by West Lake yesterday?
Sun Yuwei: Who is it? Come on, tell me, don't keep me in suspense.
Shen Wei: It's your college roommate, Zhou Lin! She said she's been interning in Hangzhou for almost a month now, working as a content operator at a well-known internet company.
Sun Yuwei: Wow! Linlin went to Hangzhou? She didn't even mention it in the dorm group chat! How is she?

Shen Wei: Pretty good, seems quite adjusted. She said the internship is very busy, but she's still finding time to plan a short video series. It seems to be about the lifestyles of young people like her in cities such as Hangzhou, Shenzhen, and Chengdu, aiming to find some unique perspectives. She also asked about you.
Song Wen: Yuwei, what have you been writing lately? I'm stuck on choosing a narrative perspective. I always feel that first-person is too narrow, while third-person feels too distant.

Sun Yuwei: I'm polishing the prose section about my trip to Dali. In terms of perspective, I've recently become somewhat fascinated with alternating between first-person experience and third-person observation, as if I am both the participant and the observer, which adds more layers to the narrative.
Song Wen: That's an interesting approach! What about the details? Are there any particular imagery you favor?

Sun Yuwei: Yes, I do. I particularly enjoy observing and describing specific moments in the growth of plants, such as the spreading boundary of moss on a wall corner, or the nearly invisible new sprout emerging from a succulent on the balcony. I believe that within these subtle dynamics lies a profound sense of time and vitality.
Capturing "the moment of plant growth"... This perspective is so delicate and truly suits your temperament. I'm inspired! I'm going to observe my pothos plant as well.

Sun Yuwei: Xiaoya, you know I've been stuck with my writing lately. Last week, I went to the bookstore I often visit and had a chat with the owner. He recommended "Ways of Seeing" to me, saying it's very helpful for understanding visual storytelling. There's also a book about Hopper's paintings that's quite inspiring, and I'm reading it now. I feel like my thinking has really opened up!
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, what are you up to? I just finished a video call with Xinran, and she seems a bit down.
Sun Yuwei: I just finished writing the draft and was about to take a break. What's wrong with Xinran? Is the work pressure too high?

Zhang Jing: It's not about work, it's a personal matter. Her upstairs neighbor recently started renovating, and the sound of the electric drill goes on from morning till night. She can't concentrate on her work at home at all, and she can't sleep well at night either. She's on the verge of a breakdown.
Sun Yuwei: Oh my god, that's so torturous. Did she communicate with the property management or the neighbors?

Zhang Jing: I've communicated with them, but they said they were working within the stipulated hours, and the property management could only mediate. She has been wearing noise-canceling headphones lately or simply working at a café, but that's not a sustainable solution in the long run.
Zhou Lin: Yuwei, how are you getting along with your new camera? The photos you posted on your Moments show such great improvement!
Sun Yuwei: Still figuring it out! But lately, I've been enjoying using that 50mm f/1.8 prime lens more and more.
Zhou Lin: Oh? Why do you particularly like this one? I noticed you previously studied wide-angle and telephoto lenses as well.

Sun Yuwei: Wide-angle lenses capture breathtaking landscapes, while telephoto lenses can "sneak shots" of distant people and objects, but they feel a bit detached from everyday life. The 50mm focal length is closest to the human eye's perspective, making the images it captures feel very authentic. Moreover, the bokeh effect created by a large aperture is simply enchanting—whether photographing a journal, floral arrangements, a corner of a café, or capturing a quiet side profile of Jingjing, the atmosphere instantly comes to life. It’s particularly well-suited for documenting my kind of "quiet" daily life.
Zhou Lin: Got it! So this is the "visual storytelling" you're pursuing, right? Using the simplest perspective to capture the most heartfelt images. Looking forward to your new work!
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, have you heard from Xinran? It seems like something major has happened on her end.
Sun Yuwei: Huh? I haven't heard anything. What's going on? Wasn't she doing well at Tencent all along?

Zhang Jing: It's just not good! She didn't go into too much detail in the group chat last night, but from what I gathered, her company recently underwent a major organizational restructuring, and many business lines were cut.
Sun Yuwei: Oh my goodness, what about the social product that Xinran is in charge of? She has poured so much effort into it.

Zhang Jing: It's the line she was in charge of. I heard the entire division has been eliminated. She's in a very awkward position now and might face layoffs. We need to think about how to comfort her.
Xu Mingyuan: Yuwei, I've read your recent prose manuscripts about the streets and alleys of Kunming. It seems you've been exploring some new stylistic approaches?

Sun Yuwei: You have a keen eye, Editor Xu. Indeed, I am trying to adjust my narrative approach. When writing cultural observations in the past, I always aimed for objectivity and comprehensiveness, but now I feel that approach creates a certain distance.
Xu Mingyuan: Could you elaborate? Is it a change in perspective?

Sun Yuwei: Yes. I now prefer to write from the first-person perspective of "I," focusing solely on what "I" see, hear, and think. For example, when writing about Wenlin Street, I would describe what I observed one afternoon by the window of Mingyuan Bookstore and the childhood memories it evoked.

Sun Yuwei: Writing this way may narrow the perspective, but it feels more authentic and carries a higher emotional intensity. It's somewhat like blending inner monologue with external observation. I wonder if readers might find it too personal?
Good evening, Coach He. I have arrived at the gym. Is the Wednesday class still at the usual time?

Mom, my older sister just sent me a message saying she has booked a ticket to return to Kunming before National Day, and she should arrive around the end of the month. She wants to give us a surprise, so let’s not tell Dad for now.
Yuwei, I've received your sister's flight information. She will arrive at Changshui Airport at 9 PM on the 28th. Please go and pick her up. I'll handle things with your dad.

Yuwei, for the next column, you could focus on the enduring spiritual legacy of the National Southwestern Associated University in Kunming. I've been reading a relevant book recently, and the author has done a very thorough job. I recommend it for inspiration. I'll send you the title later.

By the way, the book I mentioned to you last time is called "Southbound and Northbound." I particularly admire Mr. Yue Nan's writing style, which combines grand narratives with warm, detailed touches. Uncle Qin's bookstore should have it.

Vivi! I have something to share with you... I think I'm in love! He's my colleague's brother, also a teacher. He's incredibly gentle and thoughtful, and today he even gave me a collection of poems that you might like.
Yuwei, Jingjing is bringing her new boyfriend Zhao Chen out to dinner with us this weekend. I heard he's a physics teacher who enjoys science fiction. I'm already curious, how about you?

Dear Yuwei, 

The school has recently established collaborative internship programs with several local cultural institutions. I believe the literary editor position at one of the publishing houses aligns well with your career aspirations. I have already recommended you to them, and I will send you the specific details via email.

Yuwei, I heard you're also coming to intern at our publishing house? That's wonderful! Teacher Wu mentioned you when he called my supervisor yesterday. Although Kunming Literature and Art Publishing House isn't very large, it has a great atmosphere and is very suitable for you.

Yuwei! There's an amazing music festival in Chengdu this October with an incredible lineup, including a band I've been looking forward to for a long time! Let's go together, and we can also visit bookstores and check out some exhibitions. I'll send you the poster!

I saw the music festival poster you posted, the lineup is really strong. No Party for Cao Dong, Omnipotent Youth Society... so many acts I want to see! Is Haruko going specifically for No Party for Cao Dong? I remember she's been talking about them for a long time.
Daughter, I have a class reunion tonight and won't be back for dinner. Please let your mother know.
Yuwei, I just ran into your dad downstairs. He was dressed quite smartly and said he was going to the Green Lake Hotel for a class reunion. Your husband Sun is still so nostalgic.

By the way, have you noticed a young author named 'Lin Qingran' recently? His writing style is quite distinctive, featuring a somewhat 'sharp-tongued' dark humor, and he has gained some popularity within a small circle.

Didn't you mention that a writer known for his "sharp-tongued" style has been trending recently? What's his name again? I've just launched a cultural observation column and want to write about this kind of style.

Regarding Lin Qingran, whom we mentioned last time, his new book "City Whispers" has been released, and the response has been even better than expected. The style is indeed unique; you might want to keep an eye on it.
Received! I'll go buy a copy to read right away. Thank you for the recommendation, Editor Xu.

Our company is set to launch a new product in the second half of the year, which is bound to make a huge splash. It focuses on seamless cross-language communication and currently carries the internal codename 'Project Echo'.
That sounds really cool! What specific form does it take? Is it headphones? Or an app?
The "Project Echo" I mentioned to you last time has been officially named and released as the "Lingxi Smart Translation Earpods." Today's launch event was absolutely phenomenal!
Wow! I saw the news! Congratulations! That's such a great name.

There's a recent exhibition here on 'Oriental Aesthetics and Modern Design' that is exceptionally high in quality. I feel you would definitely enjoy it. You really should come see it if you have the chance.
That sounds wonderful! Where exactly is it being exhibited? And until when?
I went to see the 'Oriental Aesthetics' exhibition last weekend, and the actual pieces were ten times more impressive than the pictures! The art scene in Shenzhen is getting better and better.
I'm genuinely envious! Once I finish catching up on the progress of my essay collection manuscript, I must find an opportunity to visit you in Shenzhen.

Yuwei, if you happen to visit a bookstore recently, you might want to look for Gu Xiang's "Zhaoqiao Village." It is a severely underrated collection of essays, written in a remarkably distinctive style, which should offer you great inspiration for your own essay collection.
Thank you, Teacher Wu, for the recommendation! I've made a note of it and will go to the bookstore to look for it this weekend.
Hello Uncle Qin, I'd like to ask if your store has Gu Xiang's "Zhaoqiao Village"? It was recommended by my supervisor.
Xiaoyu, what a coincidence. I just got two copies of this obscure book. I've set one aside for you at the counter.
Yuwei, I might go to Shanghai to attend a short-term ikebana workshop. I heard they've invited a national treasure-level master from Japan. This opportunity is simply too rare to miss!
Excellent! Which master is it? I'm so envious!
Just got back from Shanghai! Master Kawase Toshiro's class was absolutely mind-blowing—it completely opened up a whole new world for me. I brought back a signed art book from him for you.
Oh my goodness! Kawase Toshiro! Thank you so much, Manman! This gift is truly precious! I can't wait to meet up and hear you share your experience!
I'm so sad. My favorite online column, "Journey on Paper," has suddenly announced an indefinite hiatus. The author mentioned running out of inspiration and needing a long period of reflection.
Ah! I've been following this column too! The writing is exceptionally spirited. What a shame—I hope the author can regain their form soon.

Do you remember "Journey on Paper"? I was flipping through old magazines at the library today and unexpectedly discovered that the author had published a series of poems under a pseudonym in their early years, maintaining a consistent style throughout.
Really?! This discovery is amazing! Could you please share the journal number and pen name?
Daughter, we're having a family dinner this Sunday evening. Your mom has already picked the place. I heard the food there is quite good, with fresh mushrooms available.
Mom said we reserved a private room at 'Dian Wei Xuan' (Wuhua Branch) for Sunday. Their mushroom hotpot is the signature dish. Both your dad and I think it suits the whole family's taste.
I recently watched an old film called "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy." It's both absurd and philosophical, and you might enjoy it. I'll send you the source file.
I'm here again to recommend a movie! Bi Gan's "Long Day's Journey into Night" – the cinematography and atmosphere are absolutely stunning, perfect for people like us who write to find inspiration.

Yuwei, the last City Observation column was well-received. For the next issue, we plan to explore another topic related to "localness." The independent bookstore scene in Kunming might be a good angle. Are you interested in writing about it?
The previous draft on 'locality' was very well written. For the next quarter, we plan to develop a series centered around this core concept, and your writing style is well-suited for it.

Xiao Sun, a signed copy of Jin Yucheng's "The Shuffling Years" has just arrived. I recall you mentioned wanting to collect his works, so I've reserved a copy for you. Feel free to come pick it up when you have time.
I recently came across a copy of Dong Qiao's "Stories" in excellent condition. Knowing you have been looking for his essay collection, I am keeping it for you.
Vivi, I'm going back to Kunming at the end of the year to attend a wedding. We should definitely get together then. You must know the groom!
I forgot to mention, the wedding at the end of the year is Brother Yuan's! He's finally getting married, and the bride is also from Kunming.

Yuwei, I heard that Sisi's art gallery (Kunming Contemporary Art Gallery) will host a young artists' installation exhibition next month. The theme revolves around 'memory,' which should be quite interesting.

I saw a notification that Yunnan University's art museum is hosting a special exhibition on ancient book restoration. Many of the exhibits are rare Ming and Qing dynasty editions from the museum's collection, and I thought you might be interested.
Vivi, I've sent you something you'll like. It should arrive in a couple of days.
Mom, have you received the flower cakes sent by your sister? She said she mailed them yesterday.
Yuwei, Uncle Qin mentioned that the bookstore will host a small reading sharing session in a few days, focusing on prose from the Republican era, which aligns with your interests. We can go together.
By the way, for the book club at Uncle Qin's bookstore tomorrow, let's meet at the entrance at 2 PM. I checked the date—it's June 2nd, the day after Children's Day.
Sun Yuwei, regarding the topic selection for your next column, you may refer to these two books: "Yunnan Local Chronicles" and "Border Town Notes."

Have you finished reading the two books I recommended last time? I just thought of another one called "Old Photos of Dianchi Lake," which tells the stories behind old photographs of Kunming. It might give you some new inspiration.
Yuwei, I've bought you a small gift to celebrate the one-year anniversary of your column! It's a pen, which you'll definitely find useful for writing. Wait for the delivery!
Have you received the LAMY fountain pen that Xinran sent you? She said the color is called 'Lilac Purple,' which matches your journal quite well.
Daughter, after the Mid-Autumn Festival, I need to visit a retired former colleague who helped me a lot when he worked at the Cultural Affairs Bureau.

Yuwei, today is the Mid-Autumn Festival. Your dad mentioned that his workplace distributed a lot of fruit. He has scheduled a visit to that old colleague’s home for the day after tomorrow, which is October 2nd.
Yuwei, I've discovered a new platform called 'Between the Lines' that specifically accepts non-fiction essays and offers decent payment. You should give it a try!

I've discovered two more treasure platforms: 'Story Bag' and 'Paper Mountains and Rivers'. The former collects urban stories, while the latter focuses more on cultural travel. I've sent you the links.

Daughter, tonight I had a serious conversation with your mother about our family's future. We have made an important decision, which is based on thorough communication and comprehensive consideration between the two of us. We hope for your understanding and support.

Zhang Lin: I recently took a mindfulness eating course and learned a method of not forcing myself. This has led me to decide to try 'vegetarian on weekdays, flexible on weekends' starting next month. It feels more sustainable this way and not too rigid.
Editor Li: Apologies, the payment of the manuscript fee will be delayed until mid-November due to financial review. Please wait patiently.
Zhang Jing: Yuwei, it's been a while since we had a proper chat. How about meeting at the usual spot tomorrow at 2:30 p.m.? That's the Time Café on Wenlin Street.
Teacher Lin: Sun Yuwei, the vocal class is at Yueyin Studio. Remember to arrive on time.
